en: The carillon of Boisson is located in the commune of Allègre-les-Fumades. The first mention of this church dates back to 1502. In 2012, during the revision of the roof of the church, the masons discovered a set of beams bearing the initials of the journeyman carpenter and the date 1566. The carillon was installed in 1892 by Ch. Aragon, an engineer-founder in Lyon, at a time when the parish found exceptional development thanks to the dynamism of the parish priest of the time, Canon Eugène-Louis Evesque, who worked for the parish from 1873 to 1921. It is the only carillon with 10 bells in the Gard. These are moreover signed by Ch. Aragon. Some of the bells have the date 1889, which allows us to assume that the bell tower was built in two phases. A one-octave electric keyboard also signed Aragon and a set of very old external hammer magnets are still in place. It is very likely that this system is contemporary with the bells. It could thus be one of the oldest electrified sets. At the beginning of the 90s, a company from Hérault worked on its restoration, also allowing the installation of a more modern traditional carillon allowing the recording of 90 combinations of melodies, due to the lack of a carilloneur, while keeping the old electric keyboard. You will be able to hear the carillon ringing at Angelus time, morning, noon and evening.
fr: Le carillon de Boisson se situe sur la commune d’Allègre-les-Fumades. La première mention de cette église date de 1502. En 2012, lors de la révision du toit de l’église, les maçons ont découvert un ensemble de poutres portant les initiales du compagnon-charpentier et la date de 1566. Le carillon est installé en 1892 par Ch. Aragon, ingénieur-fondeur à Lyon, au moment où la paroisse trouve un développement exceptionnel grâce au dynamisme du curé de l’époque, le chanoine Eugène-Louis Evesque qui œuvra pour celle-ci de 1873 à 1921. Il est le seul carillon à 10 cloches du Gard. Celles-ci sont d’ailleurs signées de Ch. Aragon. Certaines cloches comportent la date de 1889, ce qui permet de supposer que l’ensemble campanaire a été construit en deux phases. Un clavier électrique d’une octave signé Aragon également et un ensemble d’électro-aimants à marteaux extérieurs très anciens sont toujours en place. Il est fort probable que ce système soit contemporain des cloches. Il pourrait ainsi s’agir de l’un des ensembles les plus anciennement électrifiés. Au début des années 90, une entreprise héraultaise a œuvré à sa restauration, permettant également d’y installer un carillon traditionnel plus moderne permettant l’enregistrement de 90 combinaisons de mélodies, faute de carillonneur, cela tout en conservant l’ancien clavier électrique. Vous pourrez entendre le carillon sonner à l’heure de l’Angelus, matin, midi et soir.

en:
The carillon of Boisson is located in the commune of Allègre-les-Fumades.
 The first mention of this church dates from 1502. In 2012, during the revision of the roof of the church, the masons discovered a set of beams bearing the initials of the journeyman carpenter and the date of 1566. The carillon was installed in 1892 by Ch. Aragon, an engineer-founder in Lyon, at a time when the parish was developing exceptionally well thanks to the dynamism of the parish priest of the time, Canon Eugène-Louis Evesque, who worked for the parish from 1873 to 1921. It is the only carillon with 10 bells in the Gard
These are signed by Ch. Aragon. Some of the bells bear the date 1889, which suggests that the carillon was built in two phases. A one-octave electric keyboard also signed by Aragon and a set of very old external hammer electromagnets are still in place. It is very likely that this system is contemporary with the bells. It could thus be one of the oldest electrified sets
In the early 90's, a company from the Hérault region worked on its restoration, which also allowed the installation of a more modern traditional carillon allowing the recording of 90 combinations of melodies, because there was no carillonneur, while keeping the old electric keyboard.
You will be able to hear the carillon ringing at the time of the Angelus, morning, noon and evening.
